Here's a few examples my own experiences with solutions like this:

We have two types of tests: those that test our persistence layer and those
that test the layers above the persistence layer. Testing our persistence
layer is slow because we're actually testing that it properly reads and
writes to the database. Very slow. So slow that we tend to avoid running the
tests, which can be painful later.

Testing layers above the peristence layers is fast because we mocked out the
persistence layer. Those tests get run a lot and we can be sure that any
failures in these tests are not the fault of the persistence layer. Before
we mocked out the persistence layer, database access bugs had a large and
alarming ripple effect. One code change could cause dozens of seemingly
unrelated tests to fail.

We don't have individual databases, we share a test database. Imagine what
happens when two people run the same test at the same time against the same
database. If your tests aren't really careful about what data they delete,
you're going to have a lot of frustration.

We still run functional tests that exercise the complete system. There's
always the odd case where the code does exactly what it's supposed to do but
not what somebody else is expecting.
